PM

Here's what Daiju Aoki of UBS reckons

PM

We expect a powerful package of ¥20tn in increased QQE
purchases and a cut in the interest on excess reserve rate (IOER) of 20bp to -0.30%.
The BoJ is also likely to apply a negative rate on its lending facility

PM

So lots more QE

11:11 am
PM

And negative rates

PM

Economic sentiment and market conditions have worsened considerably
Conditions are no longer such that the BoJ can stand by if it is to maintain expectations
of achieving its 2% inflation target. The currency has strengthened considerably,
manufacturing conditions in the Tankan survey have deteriorated sharply and inflation
expectations have also fallen.

PM

The yen is not as strong as it was just recently

11:12 am
PM

111 agains the $ currently

PM

But still

PM

More from UBS

11:12 am
PM

An easing of fiscal policy also to come later in the spring
On the timing of the move, we think Japan also needs to show it is working to avoid a
global recession in the run-up to hosting the G7 summit on 26–27 May. The Japanese
government seems keen to demonstrate its leadership to other nations by
implementing a large monetary policy stimulus. In addition, we expect a supplementary
budget and a further delay to the consumption tax hike in April–May. A fiscal and
monetary policy mix at the same time would likely help support both corporate and
market sentiment.

PM

What is the likely market reaction?
A strong easing of a 20bp cut in the IOER and a ¥20tn increase in QQR as we expect
should lead to a strong move upward in USDJPY. This would serve to underline our
year-end forecast of 122, something which might be under threat with a less-active
BoJ. In rates markets we would initially expect some bull-flattening at the long end of
the curve, as an increase in QQE is likely not fully priced in. However we would expect
long-term interest rates to rise again with rising inflation expectations over time. For
equities, we estimate that TOPIX would rise by about 5%. The manufacturing industry,
finance, and real estate sectors should outperform other sectors.

PM

What’s priced in?
We believe that extra QQE is priced to some extent: the sharp fall in 30-year JGB yields
since the March meeting we think is partly in response to the BoJ’s monetary policy
statement which seemed to move away from rate cuts as a preferred policy tool. Our
best guess is that the market is expecting an increase of ¥10tn a year in QQE
purchases. The overnight index swap (OIS) market is pricing a decline of 15bp in the
overnight call rate in BoJ reserve maintenance periods until August, with a smaller
decline thereafter.

11:13 am
PM

How would markets react to other BoJ policy outcomes?
Inaction at the April meeting without strong assurances of further easing could be
interpreted by the market as a confirmation that the BoJ has de-prioritised the
exchange rate ahead of the G7 summit in May. (Indeed, we might also re-assess the
BoJ’s reaction function and our outlook for the yen in that case). Yields would likely rise
across rates curves – with bear steepening in the long end - and equity prices would
likely fall, led by export and consumer sectors. We provide a flow diagram to show the
market moves that we would expect in each of the more probable BoJ policy outcomes.

PM

There's going to be no option in Japan other than to mutualise everything

PM

In terms of risers, though, we have The Artist Formerly Known as Imperial Tobacco leading us up.

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,697, up 125 (+3.50%), High: 3,704, Low: 3,588, Volume: 1.10m
BE

Which is on the back of a Goldman upgrade.

11:21 am
BE

Deutsche also pushing, but we'll do Goldman first.

BE

Source of opportunity
We upgrade our rating to Buy (from Neutral) on recent underperformance;
down 8% (Euro adj) over the past month vs our European staples coverage
and the broader market (MSCI Europe). Our Buy thesis is predicated on the
company’s highly cash-generative business model (we forecast over £13bn
of free cashflow generation over the next 5 years, equivalent to 39% of its
current market cap), attractive average EPS growth (7% pa) and dividend
yield (c.5% pa) in CY17-18E, and undemanding Vuma consensus and
valuation (34% CY16E P/E discount to European staples). Our price target
implies 9% upside and a dividend yield of over 4% over the next 12 months.
Catalyst
Upcoming catalysts include 1HFY16 results on May 4 and the company’s
Investor Day on June 8. We see potential for an earnings beat of c.4%,
based on the latest Vuma consensus. In our view, the consensus is not
adequately reflecting the mix benefits from the inclusion of the US assets
and the mix effect on operating margins due to lower sales in Iraq and
Syria. In addition, based on average ytd and current FX spot rates, we
estimate a 1.5% positive contribution to FY17 tobacco operating profits. Our
FY15 EPS forecast is c.5% ahead of the consensus. At the Investor Day,
while we expect no change to management’s long-term guidance, an
update on strategy (particularly on the US and brand optimization
programs) could drive improved sentiment.
Valuation
Our unchanged 12-month price target of 3950p is based 70% on our P/E
framework (CY17E P/E of 13.5x) and 30% on our M&A value (CY16E
EV/EBITDA of 15.1x). Imperial trades at a CY16E P/E of 14.6x versus tobacco
peers BAT on 17.6x, JTI on 21.2x and PMI on 21.5x.
Key risks
Unfavourable FX, lower-than-expected performance in the US (brands) and
UK (plain packaging), a more challenging pricing environment.

BE

So, yup, straight valuation call.

11:22 am
BE

Ditto Deutsche.

BE

Imperial is c9% below intra-day highs. H1 results due 4 May. We believe the
risk to our 111p EPS forecast is c2-3% to the upside. We expect decent
commentary out of the USA and Philip Morris data re EU for calendar Q1 was
supportive. H1 sees Imperial lap the issues of Syria and Iraq meaning
communication will be less complex from H2. Carries c47p H1 dividend, paid
quarterly; goes ex c24p at end of May/end of August. Ex this c47p the stock is
all but on its 200 day moving average of 3513p. Imperial has bounced off at, or
close to the, 200-day moving average five times post emergence of
Reynolds/Lorillard/Imperial press stories in February ‘14.

BE

Regarding the court ruling re UK plain packs: consensus is the industry will
lose; we didn’t see it as an issue for the shares ahead of the recent sell-off and
don’t now. We note the legal arguments for the industry prevailing. Imperial
has an investor event on 7/8 June; we believe investors will come away more
comfortable with Imperial’s strategy (including that in the USA). Trades on
14.2x FY17E P/E and yields 4.8%. Staples on c21x and 2.8%. Once again, just
too cheap, in our view.

11:27 am
PM

One of the two shops

PM

Following its FY15 trading statement, ALM's detailed results are as expected. The Group Subsidiary Ownership Adjusted Value (GSOAV) increased by 10% to $535.8m, primarily as a result of Federated Wireless (FW) and Precision Biopsy following funding rounds and continued progress over the past year. At FW, there is good momentum in developing the ecosystem for spectrum sharing - activity in the alliance of leading telecom operators, network equipment vendors, semiconductor vendors and FW (announced at Mobile World Congress in February 2016) continues to build towards trials during the course of summer 2016 and there are good prospects for further industry leaders to join. Partially offsetting this was the decrease in valuation of RF Biocidics and CryoXtract following lower than expected sales and ALM has closed SiEnergy as expected. Nearly a quarter of the portfolio value continues to be associated with the value of STT, which remains unchanged y-on-y but we expect it to continue to build on the technology demonstrator completed in 2015. Commercially, STT is looking to establish additional partnerships and early customer relationships in addition to the 2015 co-development agreement (we understand to be with Western Digital). ALM's total cash was $194.8m at year end (of which $115m is held at the parent level), slightly lower than our expectations due to significant increases in R&D spend as ALM ramps up investments in co.s such as FW, STT, SciFluor and Precision Biopsy. We view 2016 as an important year as the portfolio transitions towards commercialisation particularly for STT, Optio Labs and expect further validation from on-going trials at FW and SciFluor - we await further data points for greater insight. ALM trades at 1.9x NAV, which compares to the remainder of the IP commercialisation sector on a range of 0.9x-1.5x.

PM

ALM invested $102.8m in its 23 portfolio co.s including $63.6m from fund-raising (of which $42.2m came from outside ALM) into SciFluor, Precision Biopsy and the remaining $39.2m into existing and new businesses; ABLS I, II, BridgeSat and HawkEye. During 2016, FW has raised $22m and expects to conduct field trials throughout 2016, 2017 with tech partners to include Ruckus Wireless, Google, Intel, Qualcomm and Nokia. ALM started ABLS III during 2016 and has 21 technologies in 'early due diligence', 2 in final DD and a no. of opportunities in active negotiations. ALM's previous OAV of $488m as at 27 Apr 15 included an uplift from SciFluor and we note uplift from Precision Biopsy of $45.6m and FW of $51m, i.e. a total of $97m offset by a write-off of ALM's holding in SiEnergy Systems (fuel cell technology) - valued at $15.3m and a reflection of the reg. hurdles at RFB, with its OAV reduced from $61.8m to $40m. OAV does not yet ascribe a value to ALM's JV with BMS - which has now sourced 3 novel therapeutic spin-outs from Yale, Harvard and NYU. As previously disclosed, FY15 revs of $3.3m were lighter than expected (NSe $5m) and we continue to expect 2016 to be a year of further investment before sales start to accelerate from 2017. In terms of catalysts we expect SciFluor to report phase I trial results in H2 2016 and anticipate further insight from ongoing development at FW and STT throughout 2016.

11:36 am
BE

Peel Hunt can walk us through it.

BE

The company led with a cautious statement at the interims. The
disruption to marketing booking patterns referred to then has
accelerated in the final part of the year. This has impacted both
the legacy business (not unexpected) but also the Strategic
Marketing operations (which the market will be disappointed to
see). This combined with a process of destocking in books results
in reductions in expectation across all three division. Forecasts
will reduce by 20% for this year and next. The speed at which
fortunes have reversed will disappoint the market, with an
assumption that more pressure will come. We place our target
price and recommendation under review.

BE

Books: The books division is seeing the headwinds of warehousing
reorganisation and a broader destocking. Moreover, the complexity of the PRH
work is greater than expected, and some export work is being lost. Whilst it is
logical to think these issues are one-off in nature and should work through, a level
of uncertainty will remain. There is considerable margin pressure as a result.
Marketing activation: The market will have expected ongoing pressure from the
UK grocery market. Forecasts here had been trimmed in recent months. There
have, however, been significant contract cancellations that have exacerbated the
trend. It is hard to see this issue as a one-off in the same way as the book
destocking.
Strategic marketing: Here the market will be more discomforted. The
previously very strong trends that had more than offset the issues in legacy
businesses have given way to some material contract cancellation. Whilst each
cancellation may have a specific cause, the coincidence of timing is disquieting.
The positive messages from November (clear evidence of collaboration and
benefit, so common ownership) will be tested in these more difficult
circumstance.
Impact on forecasts: The greatest pressure will be seen in Books (profit down a
third), with strategic marketing down just over 10%. Revenue for the full year
will be c£362m vs £372.4m current forecast. EBIT, however, will fall by £7m to
£33m, giving PBT of c£30m (from £37.2m). EPS of 16.8p vs 21.1p. In FY2017,
PBT will be nearer £32m from £41m, giving EPS of c17.3p.
Recommendation: We reduced our recommendation from Buy to Add when the
first cautious statement was issued in the interims. The subsequent fund raising at
215p, which was well supported, will not be forgotten. The broad-based nature
of the warning – with work lost across all divisions – will unsettle the market
more than a single one-off problem. As such, marginal buyers will now take some
time to be convinced this cycle has ended rather than just begun. The reasons we
liked the story before today remain intact, but we anticipate that the execution
will now take longer to validate. TP and recommendation under review.

11:37 am
BE

Numis also, if only for the new forecasts.

BE

Strategic Marketing. Although organic growth has been +15% ytd, the group has experienced greater caution in marketing budgets and has suffered the cancellation and deferral of a number of significant projects. We lower our EBITA forecasts by £3.6m to £20.2m in FY16 and £3.3m to £24.0m in 2017. We view the project deferrals to be a short term issue and expect the division to rebuild over the next 12-18m.
Marketing Activation. Trading conditions in the grocery retail sector have 'worsened' leading to revenue and margin pressure. We lower our EBITA forecasts by £2.0m to £8.0m for FY16 and £3.5m to £6.7m for 2017.
Books. Despite securing the PRH contract, St Ives has been impacted by destocking across the market following a reduction in warehouse capacity. We lower our EBITA forecasts by £2.2m to £5.0m for FY16 and by £3.4m to £4.5m in 2017.
Forecasts. We lower our PBT/EPS forecasts by -19% to £30.4m/17.5p (was £38.3m/21.6p) and by -22% to £32.4m/17.8p (£42.5m/23.0p) for 2017. We expect a maintained dividend of 7.80p. We forecast net debt/EBITDA of 2.0x for 2016 and 1.7x for 2017, compared with covenants of 2.50x and 2.25x.

BE

TED is unique. The brand's quirkiness, quality offering at affordable prices, nimble
business model and international expansion potential remain attractive features of the
group.

BE

"quirkiness" ...............

BE

Attractive opportunity. TED's c40% FY1 PE multiple contraction of the past five months
(to 18x from 30x in mid-Nov) appears overdone when compared to the 11-13% derating of
the UK General Retail (12.5x from 14.5x), Euro STOXX Retail (20x from 22x) and MSCI Luxury
Goods (16x from 18x). This also holds true when benchmarked against compounders ABF/
HMB/ITX (-10% to -20% over the same period). As such we lower our target by 12% to
3000p, broadly reflecting the sector derating, but with c25% upside and a 2% dividend
yield, we believe this is an attractive entry opportunity for the longer term and upgrade our
rating to Buy.
Rerating potential. We believe earnings growth will progressively reaccelerate post the
drag of a Pan-Euro DC move, double-running systems implementation and London HQ
acquisition in FY17E. Absorbing these costs at a time of slowing consumer spend while
broadly maintaining profitability is a respectable feat in our view, and a testament to TED's
proven track record.
Valuation/Risks
Our 3000 PT values TED on c23x 2017 PE, lower end of 3yr range of 20x-30x, but broadly
in line with European clothing peers. This translates into 1.3x 3YR TSR of 18% (16% EPS
CAGR + 2% yield) vs peers on 14% TSR. Risks: Fashion misses, significant weakening of UK/US consumer spend, execution risk in international markets.

BE

They reckon M&S and Primark to pick up share .............. which seem quite far apart on pricing to me.

BE

BHS is the 12th largest clothing retailer in the UK, generating c.£600m of revenue from 164 stores. The likely closure of these stores should offer market share to peers. Given the BHS demographic, M&S and Primark look best positioned to benefit, followed by Next and Debenhams.

BE

BHS trading details
Sales c.£600m
BHS clothing split
Womenswear 55%
Childrenswear 25%
Menswear 20%

11:50 am
BE

Positioned somewhere between M&S and Primark as a primarily clothing discounter with some homeware business.
Proportion of M&S customers greater than 65 is 38.3% compared to 37.2% at BHS.
Proportion of Primark customers categorised as DE (bottom quartile of income) is 22.4% vs BHS 27.7%.

BE

Peer opportunity
Whilst it is unclear whether some stores may be saved, or acquired by other retailers, we don’t believe they are the most attractive locations, and a base case assumption would be that many of these locations are not replaced with clothing stores. As such, peers should be able to take some of the newly available market share.
BHS has c.1.2% market share of UK clothing retail, and as such peers would expect to see a c.1.2% tailwind to their LFL clothing sales.
For Next (-) and Debenhams (NR) this would be equivalent to c.2% tailwind to Group PBT.
For M&S (+) and Primark (ABF, +), given the similar demographics we expect the tailwind would be more pronounced, and assuming they could take 1.5x their fair share, this would drive closer to 2% tailwind to the UK clothing business of each.
For both this would translate to a c.2-3% tailwind to Group PBT (note each have large Food / International+Sugar businesses respectively)
Sports Direct (+) have been rumoured to be in talks surrounding the administration. We expect talks are opportunistic, with BHS difficulties providing the chance to acquire some select store locations at good value, unlikely to have a material impact on earnings.

PM

Vadim Moshkovich

PM

Vadim Moshkovich started out in the early 1990s selling apartments, vodka and oil. Next he invested in land and created Rusagro, an agro-industrial holding company that became one of Russia's largest sugar producers. In 2005 he bought land near Moscow that had once been a cooperative farm that provided milk for intelligence officers. Where cows once roamed he now plans to build a massive residential and retail development. Moshkovich resigned Russia's Federation Council in December 2014, after eight years in the upper house of Russia's parliament
